marc:datafield.marc:subfield: Papers of John Fauchereaud Grimké, U.S. Continental soldier and South Carolina jurist; of his son, Thomas Smith Grimké; and of his grandson, Edward Montague Grimké. Included are references to supplies for the Continental Army, ratification of the peace treaty between the United States and Great Britain, the activities of the North Carolina Assembly, the affairs of the Broad River Company, epistemology, and financial and personal matters. Also included are letters concerning the estates of John F. Grimké's father and of Thomas Roper, husband of Mary Smith Grimké Roper.
Thomas W. Grimes was postmaster and merchant of Greensboro, Georgia. He also worked as a clerk in the Greene County courts.

Business and routine correspondence of Thomas W. Grimes, including information on the shipment of goods from Augusta, Georgia, and the hiring of a enslaved man from Farish Carter, apparently an in-law of Grimes. A letter from William G. Grimes, Thomas's brother, describes a trip from Georgia to Washington, D.C. in 1827.

Hiram Haines (1802-?) was son of Ezekial and Mary Miller Haines of Delamore Forest, Culpepper Co., Virginia. He travelled and worked for different Virginia and North Carolina newspapers during the 1820s and 1830s. He married Mary Ann Currie Philpotts in September 1826. After heavy financial losses, he moved with his brother William Haines to a farm in Culpepper County, Virginia, in 1838.

Collection consists of personal letters from Haines to his wife, Mary Ann Currie Philpotts. Those for the years 1826-1828 give interesting descriptions of travel, and of social and economic conditions in various places in North Carolina, including Orange, Caswell, and Person counties, and the towns of Halifax, Hillsborough, Louisburg, Oxford, Raleigh, Roxboro, and Warrenton. Included also is a notebook with genealogical information on the Haines family and poetry of Hiram Haines.
Robert E. Griffith (1789-1850) was a physician, botanists, and conchologist, and medical instructor at the University of Maryland and University of Virginia.
Collection consists of two letters of Griffith (based in Philadelphia), referring to Western lands and financial matters.
John A. Grimball was Secretary of State for Mississippi (1821-1833).
Collection consists of letters to Grimball from Abram M. Scott, John A. Quitman, and Charles Lynch, soliciting political suport and seeking information on the schedules of the circuit courts.

Two letters of recommendation (1838) for John A. Guion to the Medical Naval Board of Examiners; a letter from Guion to the Board of Examiners (1838) describing his training and education; and a manuscript extract from a letter from D.S. McCauley to the U.S. Secretary of State (1834) regarding Guion's proficiency in French, Italian, and Arabic. 2 letters dated 1861 outline Guion's plans of a safe banking policy for the Confederate States while he acted as cashier for the Bank of Commerce in New Bern, N.C.
John Hiatt oaths attesting to the free legal status of James and Lucy Pully, Guilford County, North Carolina, 1844 September 21.

Two oaths by John Hiatt, sworn before James G. Millis, the acting Justice of the Peace in Guilford County, North Carolina, in which John Hiatt attests to the legal status and good character of James and Lucy Pully, two free people of color. One oath reads: "he has been acquainted with James Pully a free man of color for the last ten or twelve years that he has always passed and repassed as a free person and that he believes him to be entitled to all the privileges of a free person of color"; the second affidavit reads the same, for Lucy Pully (James's wife). The oaths each include estimated ages and physical descriptions of the Pullys, along with lists of their six children: "four girls and two boys" with their names and ages. The document pertaining to James Pully also states that he "produced papers from the County of Orange certifying his freedom." The affidavits are both signed and sealed by clerk of the court J. M. Logan at the office of Greensborough, N.C.
William Henry Grimes was a doctor in Sharpsburg, Washington Co., Maryland.

Collection consists of personal correspondence of William Henry Grimes. Topics include his unsuccessful courtship with Sallie Seymour and her later marriage to Mr. Randolph; prices of commodities and buggies in the 1850s; conditions during the American invasion of Mexico, 1847, including troop movements in Jalapa and the hanging of two Americans for the murder of a Mexican boy; and an 1861 discussion of secession and Western Maryland politics.

Thomas Wingfield Grimes, Jr. (1844-1905) was from Columbus (Muscogee Co.), Ga. He attended Emory College and University of Georgia (graduating 1863). He then served in the Confederate Army, became a lawyer, and entered state politics in 1868. He served in the U.S. Congress between 1887 and 1891.
Collection consists of letters written while Grimes was a student at Emory College, Oxford, Ga., and the University of Georgia, Athens.
Confederate captain of engineers, stationed in Charleston, S.C.
Correspondence of the officer in charge of improving defenses at Fort Moultrie, concerning labor and requisitions for materials and for ordnance supplies.
Collection consists of scattered personal correspondence between Mary Hadly and her young friends.
Robert G. Haile, of Essex County, Virginia, served in Company F of the 55th Virginia Volunteers during the Civil War.
Collection consists of Haile's letters to his wife, Mollie Haile, written during the course of the Civil War.
Confederate soldier, slaveholder, farmer, and preacher, from Selma (Dallas Co.), Alabama.
Collection consists of Griffin's personal letters commenting on social conditions, his work in the Confederate hospitals near Richmond, Va., and wartime hardships.
The Griswold family were residents of Guilford (New Haven Co.), Conn.

Collection consists of letters of three brothers, Edward, Charles, and Joel Griswold, written to their sister Lucy Griswold while serving in the Union Army. They describe camp life, activities in South Carolina, Virginia, and Florida, the siege of Charleston Harbor, 1863, the siege of Petersburg, 1864, the Lincoln-McClellan 1864 presidential election, food supplies, paid substitutes in the army, the desertion of Confederate soldiers to the Union lines, the capture of the Confederate ironclad Fingal, Lee's surrender, and the assassination of Lincoln.
Nicolai Frederik Severin Grundtvig (1783-1872), Danish author, hymn writer, pastor, and bishop of the Evangelical Lutheran Church. Based in Aasen, Denmark.
Collection consists of a sermon by Grundtvig and a picture of him clipped from a newspaper.
Guthrie was 2nd Lieut. in the 1st Kentucky Infantry during the Civil War; he lived in Murfreesboro, Tenn.
Item consists of a letter by Guthrie describing the battle of Stone's River, Tennessee, in which he had just engaged.
Bryan Grimes was commanding officer of the 4th Regiment of N.C. State Troops in the Civil War from Grimesland (Pitt Co.), N.C.

Collection consists of a letter from Grimes to Colonel W.H. Taylor, discussing punishment for deserters. Grimes writes that he disagrees with courts-martial policies of sentencing deserters to hard labor on the Richmond fortifications because it exempts them from the dangers of the battlefield.
M. T. Haderman was a Union soldier in the 3rd United States Infantry Division, from Pennsylvania.

Collection consists of letters from Haderman to "Mary Lizzie," during the siege of Petersburg, Va. He discusses camp life, picket duty, and building forts and entrenchments, and describes the Union attack on Petersburg on April 2, 1865. He complains about Southern "secesh" ladies, and describes hangings of deserters and Confederate guerillas. He also describes raiding by Union troops.
William Gridley was a wool manufacturer from West Candor, Tioga County, New York.
Business papers of a woolen manufacturer concerning orders for sacks of wool from Alexander Whilldin and Sons.

Ship's engineer for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, originally from Brunswick Co., Va. In 1873, Hackley sailed between Yokohama and Shanghai; in 1876 he was transferred to a ship running between San Francisco and Yokohama.

Letters written by Hackley while he worked for the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, describing his journeys and activities from San Francisco to Yokohama, Japan, Shanghai, China, and other ports in Central America; and commenting on missionary efforts in Japan, and on family matters. He also participated in mine speculation in Central America and confessed he lost his savings in the 1870s.

A series of six letters from Tom [Grier?] of Boston, Mass. to Ella B. Clarke of Peoria, Ill. The letters primarily reflect the couples' courtship as Grier expresses his affection for Ella Clarke and as he discusses their wedding plans. Grier's letters also describe aspects of amusements and social life in Boston, especially concerts. To a lesser extent, he also writes about his work for Grier & Co., a grain shipping business. The letters seemingly indicate that Grier's family resided in Peoria, Illinois.
Resident of Boston, Mass. and employee of Grier & Co., a grain shipping business with offices in Peoria, Ill.; Portland, Me.; and Boston.

Collection consists of letters from Abner Griffith to his father, Dr. Thomas Griffith, concerning agricultural conditions in Marion County, Florida. Topics on the development of this area of Fla. include the price of land, cultivation of fruit and vegetables, severe weather, and related crop damage.
William McCrillis Griswold (1853-1899) was a librarian, bibliographer, and indexer who resided in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

This collection consists of letters from Nicholas Murray Butler, William Torrey Harris, Lovick Pierce, and Irwin Shepard concerning an index Griswold was preparing for the National Education Association and National Teachers Association Proceedings. (This index was released in 1897.)
National Education Association of the United States
Mr. Jules Guthridge was a newspaperman and owner of The Evening News in Washington, D.C.

Collection consists of eight invitations and other social items of Mr. and Mrs. Jules Guthridge. Names mentioned include Charles Warren Fairbanks, Cornelia Cole Fairbanks, and Mrs. Theodore Richards Noyes.
